Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of DNA Transport in Electrotransfected Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Yuan, Fan
Proposal Number: 1264186

Intellectual Merits: Electrotransfection, also known as electroporation or electric field-mediated DNA delivery, is a technology that has been widely used for introducing specific genes into cells. Its applications cover both basic research and clinical treatment and prevention of diseases. However, the technology has two obstacles that are currently limiting its further development. One is the lack of design principles for guiding development of optimal electrotransfection protocols; and the other is the poor understanding of mechanisms of plasmid DNA (pDNA) transport into cells during electrotransfection. As a result, most investigators in previous studies have to rely on the trial and error approach to protocol development, which requires measurement of electrotransfection efficiency (eTE) under different experimental conditions, in terms of electric pulse sequences and electrotransfection buffers, to identify an optimal set of conditions for each type of cells. This process is inefficient and can be expensive. Furthermore, some recent studies suggest that eTE is only partially dependent on electric pulse parameters. Other parameters, such as properties of cell membrane and pathways for intracellular transport, may be more crucial for determination of eTE. To this end, the goal of the proposed study is to investigate novel mechanisms of pDNA transport during electrotransfection. The central hypothesis is that adsorptive endocytosis is a key mechanism of electrotransfection for cellular uptake and intracellular transport of pDNA. To test the hypothesis, different types of mammalian cells will be treated with molecular inhibitors or enhancers, either prior to or post their exposure to pulsed electric fields. The treatments will alter electric field-induced binding between pDNA and cell membrane, or change activities in endocytic pathways. After each treatment, kinetics of cellular uptake and pDNA transport will be measured with confocal and electron microscopy techniques, and the kinetic data will be analyzed quantitatively using various mathematical models to determine mechanisms of cellular uptake and intracellular transport of pDNA.

Broader Impact: Improvement in electrotransfection technology can broadly impact basic biomedical research since the technology has been widely used for gene transfer into target cells. It may also impact clinical applications of gene therapy and DNA vaccination, which will lead to improvement in healthcare in both developed and developing countries because electrotransfection systems can be constructed inexpensively. The proposed study will show that the efficiency of gene/vaccine delivery can be improved through optimization of DNA attachment to cell membrane and enhancement of DNA transport via endocytic pathways. The research findings are crucial for development of novel design principles and strategies for improving the electrotransfection technology in future studies. In terms of education, results from the research project will be used to improve an existing biomedical engineering (BME) course on drug and gene delivery, currently taught by the PI at Duke University, and to develop a new elective course on intracellular transport of molecules and nanoparticles. In addition, the project will be used to train individual students to do research. Graduate students, including at least one minority student, will use the project as the basis of their thesis/dissertation. Undergraduate students will be recruited to the project through the independent studies and the Pratt Research Fellow program at Duke University. Furthermore, the PI will mentor underrepresented students in an outreach program. These students will be paired with graduate students to do summer research related to the proposed study.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main educational activities in the last report period include recruiting female students from a local high school to do Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) internship in my lab, supervising underrepresented minority students. In research, we continued the investigation of mechanisms of intracellular trafficking of electrotransfected pDNA in different cells. Results from the mechanistic study were used to develop new strategies for improving electrotransfection efficiency.  

We showed that Rab5 activities were not directly correlated to the efficiency of electrotransfection, suggesting that electrotransfection was controlled by downstream factors in endocytic pathways. We also showed that the nuclear envelope was a major barrier to electrotransfection. To overcome the barrier, plasmid DNA needs to contain a nuclear localization sequence (NLS) that allows it to enter the nucleus through nuclear pore complex. Or electrotransfection needs to be performed when the nuclear envelope breaks down. These findings can be used to significantly improve applications of electrotransfection in both basic research and clinical treatment of diseases.

One undergraduate student and one PhD student worked specifically on this project. They are Mr. Brian Chan, an undergraduate student, and Ms. Lisa Cervia, a PhD student. Both are students in the biomedical engineering program at Duke University.

Brian’s research project is to establish a system in my lab for detection of fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) signals. We have used a similar system in another lab to monitor FRET signals from a Rac1 sensor. The study showed that activation of Rac1 in cells exposed to electric pulses was necessary for electrotransfection. Brian built a similar system for study of other FRET sensors.

Lisa’s research project is to develop chemical and physical methods to facilitate plasmid DNA transport in cells for electrogene delivery. Lisa has been doing very well in the lab. Results from her research have shown that electrotransfection involved novel endocytic pathways that might be different from those involved in synthetic nanoparticle-mediated gene delivery. Lisa has been very productive in research. She has published one paper, and submitted her second paper for peer review in a journal. She is working on her third manuscript and expecting to publish 5 papers as the first author, and several others as co-authors. Additionally, Lisa has shown great potential to become an independent investigator in the BME field. Because of her outstanding achievements, Lisa received the Innovation and Career Development Award at the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES)’s 2016 annual conference. Lisa has also shown leadership talent. Recently, she was elected as the President of Duke Student Chapter in BMES. Through collaboration with her colleagues in the organization, she successfully organized the first BMES conference at Duke University in November 2016.

Our lab offered internship opportunities every year to students at a local public high school, the Middle Creek High School in Apex, NC. The school curriculum contains an “Engineering & Design Academy” program, in which students, who are interested in pursuing careers in engineering and technology, will take a sequence of technology and business courses for 4 years, develop engineering design projects based on what they have learned in classes, and participate in a summer or semester internship between their junior and senior year. In the past 12 months, two female and one male students from the high school did their internship (> 135 hours per student) in our lab. They watched experiments and prepared samples for graduate students in our lab. At the end of internship, they gave presentations on what they did to a panel consisted of industry leaders in our area. It is expected that the internship experience will make most students excited about science and engineering.

One African-American undergraduate student from Georgia Institute of Technology did a summer internship in my lab in 2016. He was recruited through the Summer Research Opportunity Program at Duke University Medical Center. His research project was to numerically simulate cellular uptake of nanoparticles via endocytosis. The goal of the simulation was to show dynamic process of nanoparticle invagination by mammalian cells. The student had neither background in the study of endocytosis nor experiences numerical simulations. So, he had to start from scratch. The student did very well in the lab and was excited about the project. After he finished the internship at Duke, the student continued the research and presented a poster at a national conference by himself. At present, the student is applying for MD-PhD programs at top universities in the country. I am confident that he will be admitted by the programs.


Last Modified: 06/10/2017
Modified by: Fan Yuan
